column1: More than 300 students::: faculty::: and staff came together Wednesday for the Chancellor's Day of Service benefitting YWCA Knoxville & the Tennessee Valley to support women and families.  NEWS.UTK.EDU Volunteers Team Up for Chancellor’s Day of Service - News

If you really want to understand a person::: as the saying goes::: you must be willing to walk a mile in their shoes. That's what United States Air Force veteran and UT Knoxville Alumni Tom Cruise—no::: not that Tom Cruise—does every day for fellow veterans at UT.  Cruised thrived academically when he first arrived on Rocky Top after six years in the Air Force. But he lacked a community that understood his background as a student veteran.  By the time he graduated in 2017::: UT had opened the Veterans Success Center—and Cruise leaped at the opportunity to join the team. Now he works to identify the needs of student veterans and find the resources to address them  It takes understanding to lead and serve. It takes a Volunteer.

Nine new monuments dedicated to UT's National Pan-Hellenic Council::: also known as the Divine 9::: now have a permanent location along Pedestrian Walkway.  The Divine 9 is made up of nine historically African American sororities and fraternities. The monuments highlight the connection to the past::: as previous members of NPHC set the foundation for the present while reaffirming the university's commitment to inclusion and cultivating a culture of success for current and future students.  NEWS.UTK.EDU National Pan-Hellenic Council Honored with Monuments Dedication - News

"Do your best::: don't let anything knock you off your path::: and always help others along the way."  A true torchbearer::: this is the life philosophy UT Knoxville Alumni Brenda Lewis Peel has lived by. Peel became the first Black undergraduate student to earn a bachelor's degree from the university in 1964::: and she's been dedicated to ensuring access to education for all students ever since.  It takes perseverance to pave the way. It takes a Volunteer.  UTK.EDU Paving the Way

column1: "Tennessee is home." Thanks to Candace Parker and all of our UT Knoxville Alumni and friends who came home sweet home last week for Homecoming. 🧡

Things are changing quickly in regards to mask requirements on campus. To maintain compliance with federal Executive Order 14042::: UT plans to put a mask requirement back in place for most campus buildings effective Monday::: Nov. 22.  Employees received an email from UT System President Randy Boyd yesterday lifting the mask mandate in compliance with state law. There is an executive order that requires employees of federal contractors to follow CDC mask guidance::: and UT Knoxville is a federal contractor.  Because federal funding is at stake::: the new state law allows federal contractors to apply for an exemption to the state law. President Boyd applied for an exemption on behalf of the UT System::: and we received notice of the exemption last night.  We are preparing for the mask requirement to be back in place on Monday::: Nov. 22. Until that time::: please make whatever personal choice you think is best while being respectful of those around you. We will share additional information on Monday.  CHANCELLOR.UTK.EDU Changing Mask Requirements at UT Knoxville

column1: Vols help Vols! 🇺🇸 Megan Byrd::: of UTK Student Veterans::: dedicates her time to helping fellow veterans and first-generation college students find their purpose on Rocky Top.  KNOXNEWS.COM How a veteran::: first-gen University of Tennessee student helps others get past 'hard days'

369 and counting. That's the number of Tennessee alumni who are being recognized by a new UT Armed Forces Memorial that will be dedicated in the spring.  The memorial will honor the sacrifice of students::: faculty::: and staff from all UT System campuses who died in the line of duty while in military service to the United States from World War I to the present.  NEWS.UTK.EDU Armed Forces Memorial to Honor Fallen Students::: Faculty and Staff - News
column3: Robert Reese Neyland; February 17::: 1892 – March 28::: 1962 was an American football player and coach and officer in the United States Army::: reaching the rank of brigadier general. He served three stints as the head football coach at the University of Tennessee from 1926 to 1934::: 1936 to 1940::: and 1946 to 1952. Wikipedia  On May 30::: 2016::: I was at Omaha Beach. This was a moving experience::: seeing the difficult terrain the Allied Forces faced to gain a foothold on the beach. And another moving experience seeing the attention given to the this sacred ground. I happen to find this gravesite and took this picture because it had both Texas and the name Neyland on it. I recently realized it is indeed Coach and General Robert Reese Neyland whom I saw and spoke to many times while attending The University of Tennessee. Thank you for your Military Service and Service to University of Tennessee and it’s students and Football Traditions. Peace.

"It is important to me that my students know I'm their biggest fan. I want them to leave our rotation feeling empowered to keep learning and to do what they love."  Assistant professor Jennifer Weisent's passion for animal welfare isn't just bettering the lives of shelter animals::: it's improving the quality of veterinarians graduating from UTCVM-University of Tennessee College of Veterinary Medicine.  Weisent's students receive hands-on training in surgery and anesthesia through their work with CAIT (Companion Animal Initiative of TN) while addressing overpopulation and helping to bring animals a step closer to their forever homes.  It takes teamwork to meet the needs of our community. It takes a Volunteer.  UTK.EDU Answering the Call for Animal Care

column1: "We want to know how we can improve animal welfare in East Tennessee::: whether that be breaking down language barriers for people to find bilingual veterinarians::: offering spay and neuter services to pet owners who may be homeless::: or working with shelters to set up surgical suites.”  Assistant professor Jennifer Weisent is part of the CAIT (Companion Animal Initiative of TN) Spay-Neuter Mobile Service team in the UTCVM-University of Tennessee College of Veterinary Medicine that meets the needs of animal shelters throughout East Tennessee. UTK College of Education::: Health::: & Human Sciences 14 October 2021 г.::: 14:47 ·  For 26-year-old Sierra Morris of Walland::: TN::: a lost hearing aid meant saving up $5:::000-$10:::000 for a new one::: after her health insurance provider stopped covering the cost of hearing amplifiers due to her age. However::: after learning about Tamika Catchings' Amplification Fund through University of Tennessee Health Science Center::: Sierra was able to receive a new set of hearing aids completely free of charge!  Click here to learn more about how Tamika Catchings::: a #CEHHS alumna::: continues to exemplify what it means to be a Volunteer: bit.ly/3FLWEtB  #ItTakesAVolunteer  -- University of Tennessee::: Knoxville UT Knoxville Alumni Kinesiology::: Recreation::: & Sport Studies WVLT

column31: All I'm saying is - University of Michigan showed us all up with one hell of a pre-game and half time show on 9/11. The Ohio State University and The Ohio State University Drumline and Marching Band only thinks they're the "best damned band in the land"... but moves like what the The University of Michigan Drumline and Marching Band did on 9/11 can easily find that title being given to someone else. A band that puts that kind of love::: attention::: effort::: and energy into honoring our nation and remembering those lives who have been lost - THAT is what gains you the title of "Best Danged Band in the Land". THAT kind of love shown to our country is what makes people think twice about where they're going to attend college - for so many reasons. I LOVE what they did in every way - I just wish we could have seen this kind of quality pre-game and half time show out of our southern universities who swear they love America too. Looking at you University of Tennessee::: Knoxville and University of Florida Heck::: there's still time - September is the perfect month to honor our country::: our military::: and those who have lost their lives while fighting to preserve our freedoms. Let's make this happen! Surely we're not going to let a northern university show us up like this... We're better than that.

column19: In honor of Constitution Day (September 17th)  GEORGE WASHINGTON Deemed the greatest man in the world by everyone ⁠ George Washington was famous for his humility::: and was revered as the "Greatest Man in the World" during his timeline according to scholars::: noblemen::: commoners::: and even the King of Britain whom he defeated in battle. He was also the most famous celebrity throughout the world causing people to line-up throughout the countryside just to see him ride past on his horse. ⁠ What the 400 British ships didn't see when they sailed into New York Harbor to defeat George Washington and his "ragtag" untrained Continental Army who were fighting for their independence from England's taxes and laws::: was Washington's faith in God and his humility ― the latter being his most noted characteristic of which people wrote about in their letters and diaries. ⁠ Even the other founding fathers agreed that George Washington was the best of them all::: a man with no formal education. ⁠ After Washington defeated King George III and his army after eight straight years of battling::: the King acknowledged Washington as being the best man in the world for turning down the opportunity to be ordained King (as many people wanted to see happen)::: and also for handing his devoted army back to the Congress which had never before then been done by a winning war General in order for him to return back to his farm and live out the rest of his life privately at his home although later::: he would be pressured to become the first President of the United States of America in order to continue spreading his noble::: wise and humbling influence. ⁠ Washington's army in theory::: should never have won the War for Independence (also called the Revolutionary War)::: but they did even though at times twenty-percent of the army went without shoes or clothing having to endure hot and freezing conditions including walking barefoot through frozen lakes::: cutting their feet on rocks::: and having only to eat "firecake" at times which is flour mixed water prepared in a kettle over fire thus causing many of them to die from starvation and disease when Washington somehow never got sick like the others did.  Over the years::: his army came to believe that Washington survived gunfire and disease because he was ordained by a higher-order like when a thick-mist appeared from nowhere blocking out everything in sight allowing the Continental army to escape an attack so they could regroup and strategize. ⁠ George Washington freed all his slaves before he died::: some of them had been inherited from his father during times when even African people were selling their poorest and least educated people under the justification that they weren’t like humans::: because they were primitive in culture and tradition. ⁠ It’s unfortunate that Washington::: and all the other good people couldn’t have afforded to purchase all the slaves and give them dignified jobs::: beautiful places to live::: and an educations like many did::: but there were about four million slaves in the end and nobody was rich enough to purchase them all::: especially after the invention of the Cotton Gin which rose America to being the producer of about three quarters of the world’s cotton.  This amassed some of the biggest fortunes during those times which caused many evil and greedy people to raise the price of slaves to 7 or 8 times higher AND it also posed more danger to slaves overall when talking about abolishing slavery during a time when the people making fortunes from it were never more power hungry who would rather see the slaves killed than become free as proven when they hunted down slaves after they were freed. ⁠ Washington's great friend Billy Lee was a black slave that Washington purchased and saved from a potentially horrible fate. Billy Lee::: rode aside Washington for the 8-years they fought together as a best man and friend. ⁠ Fritz Hirschfeld a historian wrote that::: "If Billy Lee had been a white man he would have had an honored place in American history because of his close proximity to George Washington during the most exciting periods of his career. But because he was a black servant::: a humble slave::: he has been virtually ignored by both black and white historians and biographers.” ⁠ George Washington::: top scholars::: innovators::: and the founding father’s who worked on developing the U.S. Constitution knew that the Constitution was better than them selves::: and that it was the best attempt to give power to the people NOT the evil that will ALWAYS find itself employed in government. ⁠ They all knew the slaves must be freed for the Constitution to become all that it was written to be::: but knew a gradual approach to freeing the slaves was the best way to protect them from being killed::: and to plan for their integration into society as free and equal people.  Many Africans came to America of their free will settling first in Portland::: the melting post of vast religions::: languages::: and foreign cultures getting along together and excited to be living and exploring the "new world" of which they didn't originally know was already inhabited by hundreds of Indian tribes::: some unfriendly like the Shawnee who captured and tortured one of Daniel Boone's sons to death::: and were known for scalping the much different looking foreigners.  Many of the tribes were friendly and showed the foreigners how to grow food and navigate through the uncharted and dangerous terrain::: some of them even partnered with the British by guiding them through forestry during the war.  Washington called the Constitution “The Great Experiment” and I personally believe it is worth dying for::: just like our Bible is and ancient history which have been removed from public education.⁠ ⁠ GEORGE WASHINGTON QUOTES:⁠ ⁠ “The fate of unborn millions will now depend::: under God::: on the conduct and courage of this army.”⁠ ⁠ To be prepared for war is one of the most effective means of preserving peace.” ⁠ “Government is not reason and it is not eloquence. It is force! Like fire it is a dangerous servant and a fearful master. Never for a moment should it be left to irresponsible action.” ⁠ “It should be the highest ambition of every American to extend his views beyond himself::: and to bear in mind that his conduct will not only affect himself::: his country::: and his immediate posterity; but that its influence may be co-extensive with the world::: and stamp political happiness or misery on ages yet unborn.” ⁠ “The time is near at hand which must determine whether Americans are to be fre

column3: Nicely done::: Vols. <3 9/11 was during my first semester in Knoxville at UT::: having moved down from just outside NYC. I started calling home after the first tower fell::: both home and work lines (no cell phones) and couldn't reach either of my parents who worked in the city::: one downtown near World Trade::: for hours because it was literally DEAD air... No busy signals::: nothing. The campus operator at the time was so sweet::: calming and maternal to me telling me to just keep trying every few hours. It's one of many things I'll never forget about that day. For anyone interested::: here's a few clippings I saved from the 9/12 Daily Beacon::: including the Rock.
column4: I got a call on my room phone on the tenth floor of Andy holt from my buddy screaming::: "We're under attack!". I looked out the window and all seemed fine. So I hung up and went back to playing twisted metal black on PS2. I few hours later I realized that we were not fine. ✌️&❤️ Vol nation.
column5: We should never forget. Our son was just one month old. We knew as we watched on TV::: life would never be the same.

As the COVID-19 delta variant continues to spread and is driving up hospitalizations in our local communities::: we are adjusting campus health and safety guidelines. Masks are now required in all indoor public spaces::: except in private offices and residence hall rooms and while individuals are actively eating::: drinking::: or engaging in fitness activities.  This new mask mandate will be in effect for the next two weeks. System and campus leadership will re-evaluate the situation by September 7.  Faculty::: staff::: and students are strongly encouraged to get vaccinated against COVID-19. This is the best defense against contracting and spreading COVID-19::: and especially against severe cases of the disease. It is also the best way to ensure that we can keep our campus thriving and bustling throughout the fall semester.  Read the complete updated mask guidance and find resources for scheduling a COVID-19 vaccine appointment at the link below.  CHANCELLOR.UTK.EDU Update to the UT Mask Policy

UTK please look to other universities who are handling this far better. UNC required proof of negative COVID tests from every student upon being allowed on campus. UNC’s student population has an 86% vaccination rate. Students who are unvaccinated must have mandatory testing on campus twice a week. That is what caring about your students looks like. I am frustrated::: angry and disappointed how poorly UTK has begun this school year.
column33: Right now::: hospitals are CRITICALLY short-staffed with nurses::: techs and basically everyone. And::: I mean CRITICALLY. Forcing this issue seems like an incredibly silly hill for hospitals to die on at this time in history. These protests are going on nationwide::: and even internationally .  1) Transmission and infection indisputably occur among the vaccinated::: who can carry the virus in the nasopharynx. Therefore::: what is the argument for forcing medical staff to accept a medical procedure that is unwanted?  2) If any group of people have a high percentage who've developed natural immunity::: due to repeated exposure over the course of the last 18 months::: this group is it. Therefore::: what is the rationale for forcing them to receive a medical treatment that is then unnecessary for them as individuals?  As an NYU researcher opined in this article:  “Medical professionals are often trained to assess the situation on an individual basis and made a recommendation::: and so the notion that there should be a universal health policy that applies to all people and that is determined by the government rather than a medical professional on a case-by-case basis::: is contrary to the way they are trained to work:::” she said.

column3: Proud Vol alum and ER doctor here::: and I think this is a wonderful idea. Those whom we are admitting::: those who are sick enough to be in danger::: are almost entirely unvaccinated at this point. The data from the phase III trials suggested a safe and effective vaccine::: and the data collected from the millions to get it since the release have only strengthened that position. What an opportunity for those who have not yet done so to get vaccinated on such Hallowed ground! And though in a free society as ours no treatment can or should be forced upon you::: no such discussion ought even be necessary as we should all be willing to do what we can to return to normalcy. Those who came before us Volunteered to eradicate smallpox and polio::: we should be proud to do the same with our own situation. Its a free country::: do what you will. but I’ve seen 109:::455 in Neyland before::: and I’d love to see more go through for this.

column1: Hard to believe it's been five years. What are your favorite memories of Coach Summitt?  Tennessee Lady Vols Basketball 28 June 2021 г.::: 08:13 ·  The best to ever do it.  June 14::: 1952 - June 28::: 2016 🧡💜
column3: Never got the chance to meet this incredible lady but sure wish I had. My son Jeff Finley had the honor of meeting Pat when he was working security at the basketball games while she was coaching. He said she sure was a nice lady and treated everyone with respect. He said she always found him at the games. She knew he would take care of her and her recruits!
column4: First time I ever met her...at a closed Lady Vol practice. We were invited to watch the girls practice. She was very gracious. My daughter was a manager for the team
column5: I worked for The Daily Beacon when I was at UT::: which was located next to the arena. When we would go eat at the arena and Coach walked in::: everyone just stood aside and let her come on through. She was a very intimidating::: strong woman. A fantastic role model.
column6: I met Pat at an Indiana Fever game in July of 2009. When she walked into the room::: I was expecting to feel this overwhelming presence of a celebrity. Instead::: I simply thought::: “Oh::: there’s Pat.” In a way that felt like I knew her. That’s who Pat was to the Lady Vol fan base. So caring::: so humble::: so personable. I consider myself incredibly lucky to have grown up with the influence of Pat Summitt. 🧡
column7: First met her in 1979 in the players lounge after a game. She immediately knew my hometown in the MO Bootheel from her days at UT-Martin. Always welcomed the early Lady Vols fans after home games. Loved her! 🧡
column8: I just loved watching her coach and the love she had for her team and her fans.
column9: Her greatness! The time she spent with my son and I at a book signing as if we were the only ones there! ❤️
column10: Wish I could remember who the LV’s were playing… she called a time out and set up a play … not sure if she wanted Holdsclaw to get the ball and make a play ::: or to be a decoy. Whatever the case::: it was obvious that Holdsclaw didn’t/ couldn’t (?) follow through. Pat called another TO and the next thing you knew :::Chamique was sitting… and::: LV’s were up around 20 points over their opponent… after givingChamique the what for::: a few minutes later :::Pat was sitting next to her with her arm around her and then sent her back in. 🧡 I guess no one player is more important than the team and their is always time to teach!
column11: Her love of basketball::: competitive spirit and love of her family
column12: I have two. I lived in Central Florida but was able to fly up for the game when Pat became the winningest coach in history::: and the court was named after her following the victory. That was awesome to see in person! I was also at National Championship #8 in Tampa. Who would have guessed that would be her last?
column13: Her Passion for coaching and seeing her on the sidelines. Oh especially her stare::: and yelling get over here from the sideline. Miss you so much Pat! #neverforgotten
column14: Before I knew who she was I would run on sundays in the winter in the stokely athletic center. it was dark. one day I passed this women and she picked up the pace and passed me. I passed her back. She passed me back and yelled "I can do this all day!" She slowed down and we ran together for about another 30 mins. When I stopped she said::: "I have seen you here before" Lets run next Sunday same time". So we did all that winter. I asked her name as I was leaving::: "Pat Head." Rest In Peace!
column15: Meeting Pat in LAX after they had just beat USC in a game::: she was the nicest person I had ever met. She was so nice to my daughter telling her to stick with playing basketball and it could take her places. It was a great moment in my life.
column16: Torch Night freshman year when she sang Rocky Top to us 🧡🤍🧡
column17: Pat Summitt. Legend. Gone far too soon.
column19: I always thought we could win any game when she was coaching regardless of the opponent.
column20: Watching her coach a game and hearing her speak in Jackson::: Tennessee
column21: I miss her integrity and her influence on young players today. She taught them to persevere and never give up. Just miss her.
column22: 🧡🍊🐐 She was the best...person::: Coach::: teacher::: motivator and VFL!!
column23: my father was a huge fan
column24: Seeing that stare in person. She intimidated ME::: and I was just a student in the stands!
column25: I grew up in California::: and became a Lady Vols fan in the 7th grade and respected Pat Summit especially. 🧡🧡🧡
column28: Winning for a change. With Pat we could actually win…
column29: She always took time to chat with fans!!
column30: I Miss her
column32: The G.O.A.T!

column1: As we mark the 225th anniversary of Tennessee Statehood::: it’s worth noting historical figures that have ties to the earliest days of the university and to the State of Tennessee.  The Rev. Samuel Czar Carrick::: founder in 1794 of UT-precursor Blount College (seen in the illustration below)::: delivered the opening prayer and sermon on January 12::: 1796::: for the Tennessee Constitutional Convention.  William Blount::: the territorial governor for whom Blount College was named::: was on the college's board. He served as president of the state constitutional convention::: where the state Constitution was signed on February 6::: 1796. Within weeks Tennessee had a governor (John Sevier) and a legislature meeting in regular sessions in Knoxville::: then the capital.  Blount was one of the first two senators who reported to Philadelphia::: expecting to find a seat there before Tennessee was even officially recognized as a state. This took place on June 1 in Philadelphia::: when President George Washington officially signed the document of statehood.
column3: Braeden Mangus
column4: Joseph McMinn was selected by Blount was to take the TN constitution to Philadelphia and not come back till they accept Tennessee as a State::: then the papers were sent to George Washington
column5: From Greeneville::: TN with the Capitol of the Lost State of Franklin::: to Knoxville::: to Nashville.  We have one of the more unique historical States in the Union.

column1: The university has worked to understand the facts and listen to the concerns related to a faculty member's use of a racially charged acronym last week as part of an Africana Studies class. We recognize::: respect::: and are sorry for the pain that this word in any form causes.  We are committed to being transparent about the facts::: concerns::: and actions taken to create inclusive learning environments for all of our students::: staff::: and faculty. We also will continue our commitments to advance equity::: diversity::: and inclusion on our campus.  We have taken and will continue to take a variety of actions aimed at education::: inclusive teaching::: and advancing understanding in and out of the classroom. You can learn more about the incident::: actions taken::: and our plans moving forward at https://news.utk.edu/2021/02/07/update-on-incident-in-africana-studies-classroom.  NEWS.UTK.EDU news.utk.edu
column3: Problem one: students who were NOT in the room complained. They didn’t have the context in which to understand. Problem two: the students taking the course outta know there will be some controversial topics-no different than all of them waking up everyday. Time to grow up and quit whining about stuff not agreed with. Guess what? Life sucks sometimes. People do things we done agree with. You don’t get to demand someone gets fired for every single thing. Problem three: some of the “offices” this university has created because of PC -ness has only done more harm than good.
column4: Anyone with an attorney friend might find it worthwhile to understand the university action and why they took that route. It’s called risk mitigation - I have seen similar actions in large corporations. The USA is so litigious - even for events like this that were taken out of context.
column5: I’m sorry::: but didn’t we ALL read “To Kill A Mockingbird:::” in high school? Words are out there. When used in relevant context::: especially when fair warning is given::: there should be no need for counseling. If you’re that sensitive::: maybe you shouldn’t be in the class.
column6: Maybe we need to stop coddling these adults and let them know that sticks and stones may break their bones::: but words written on a whiteboard can't hurt them. Wait... is "whiteboard" insensitive too? Maybe colorless board is better? Seriously people::: this is beyond insane.
column7: The University needs to check in on the other African Studies class Professor. I’m completely disappointed in what he is teaching and there’s certainly no free-thinking allowed. But::: I’m encouraging my son to think for himself and not to be intimidated.
column8: Let me explain this very clearly::: none of us were there::: we don't know the context::: we don't know the professor::: we don't know the words::: tone::: or environment surrounding this topic. But what we do know is::: UTK has a long history of not speaking out either immediately or at all about the racially charged incidents that happen at UTK::: in Knoxville::: or from the students that attend the school. It is too often I see UTK apparel draped over people who are spewing hate speech. This history in addition to this incident and who knows::: it is likely the true reason for the response of students. I remember vividly walking and seeing confederate flag draping around::: or things spray painted::: I remember being scared walking by myself at night on campus. Let's not pretend that Tennessee doesn't have a long rooted history in slavery::: confederacy::: and marginalization of POC. So yeah::: i might get upset too::: to see it::: to relive those feelings. But::: if you've never lived that reality::: I would expect to see you comment that "PC-ness" and "sensitivity" is destroying education.
column9: The university handled this very appropriately - we must learn history and any negative impact of it to avoid it in the future. The purpose of college is to open the eyes of the students to bias they may have::: but not be aware. Just because a word is written on a board in context to the class at hand is no reason to dismiss a faculty member. Helping the faculty member see how to present the topic differently is the best way.  Would any of us want to be fired for one mistake that was not intentional? I doubt any of us are perfect.
column10: Ridiculous beyond words. The acronym came from the title of a 1993 Tupac Shakur album. The acronym means "never ignorant getting goals accomplished." Exploring a legitimate piece of African American history in an Africana studies classroom is considered racist because they wrote the title on the board? The concept of academic freedom has no meaning anymore.
column11: 🤦🏽‍♀️ ...Glad to hear the teacher wasn’t fired!
column12: Racism has no place in our University. Those who are selfish enough to find every excuse to try to explain it away should return their diploma (if they ever earned one) and go find another institution. Signed::: Alum Class of '95
column13: Seeing this incident in full context I understand how this could have been offensive to some students. Personally I think it's awesome that UT didn't fire the professor but instead saw this as an opportunity for improvement.
column14: I am so ashamed to say that I not only have one but two degrees from UTK...this is no longer an institution of higher learning. We no longer have any understanding of what mature thinking is. Or educated controversy in order to be better at understanding something other than your own personal opinion and small mindset. I guess being one of the very first females ever to be hired in an all male workforce gives me no place for comment...but save your nasty comments...I’ve heard them all already. LOL...I have tough skin unlike the coddled children of today. Pitiful.
column15: Sooooooo::: just exactly how are you supposed to discuss a word or its impact on a person or society without saying that word or writing it on the board?
column16: So basically we should stop teaching anything about history since everyone and their mother gets offended.
column17: I’m so embarrassed to see that my university is caving to the woke mob. You all should be ashamed of yourselves.
column19: In other words::: nothing at all is being done.
column20: Interesting...a ll of the commentators on this thread who don’t find how this could possibly be perceived as offensive...sha re one thing in common. Have never had the perceived epithet used against them or their culture. And seem to be offended that the issue was even addressed.
column21: So not much has changed in the 30 years since I graduated!?...s ad!
column22: Why did you fire the teacher? It wasn't meant racism. If they were teaching something and have the students to think how it would effect them!
column23: So a word upsets students now ?

column1: University of Tennessee College of Arts & Sciences and department leadership is actively talking with students and faculty members about an Africana Studies class in which a faculty member wrote a racially charged acronym on the whiteboard.  Initial actions include engaging with students in the class and the department::: and we are working to bring expert scholars to this discussion. We are trying to understand the situation::: its context::: and its impact in order to chart a path forward.  We are sorry for the hurt this has caused many members of our community. We value diversity::: inclusion::: and respect::: and are working hard to create a campus where everyone matters and belongs. This work will not stop::: and we are committed to continuous learning and improvement.  Information is still being gathered::: which may precipitate additional actions. The Africana Studies program has provided additional context on its website.  AFRICANA.UTK.EDU Africana Studies Program | The University of Tennessee::: Knoxville

column20: EEO/AA Statement / Non-Discriminati on The full University of Tennessee Knoxville::: Non-Discriminat ion Statement EEO/AA statement reads as follows:  All qualified applicants will receive equal consideration for employment and admission without regard to race::: color::: national origin::: religion::: sex::: pregnancy::: marital status::: sexual orientation::: gender identity::: age::: physical or mental disability::: genetic information::: veteran status::: and parental status::: or any other characteristic protected by federal or state law. In accordance with the requirements of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964::: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972::: Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973::: and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990::: the University of Tennessee affirmatively states that it does not discriminate on the basis of race::: sex::: or disability in its education programs and activities::: and this policy extends to employment by the university. Inquiries and charges of violation of Title VI (race::: color::: and national origin)::: Title IX (sex)::: Section 504 (disability)::: the ADA (disability)::: the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (age)::: sexual orientation::: or veteran status should be directed to the Office of Equity and Diversity::: 1840 Melrose Avenue::: Knoxville::: TN 37996-3560::: telephone 865-974-2498. Requests for accommodation of a disability should be directed to the ADA Coordinator at the Office of Equity and Diversity.

column13: I need to comment about what happened to Mimi Groves. She::: of course::: is the person who was pressured into withdrawing her application for admission to UT Knoxville. I do not support racism; it has to end::: as there's no place for it. However::: apparently::: there also isn't any place for forgiveness in our Country - at least in the Court of Public Opinion. Her comment::: while hateful::: and hurtful::: was made when she was a Freshman. By the time that she was a Senior::: she apparently changed by rallying behind the BLM movement. Both appear to be obe-time events::: which begs the question: "Why was more weight placed upon the former video than the latter video?" Also wildly hypocritical is the motive behind the other student. He doesn't care how this impacted another human being: his exact frustration with bigotry::: and hatred. Somehow::: he justifies his revenge as::: "payment" for all of the suffering that he endured. Was she the ONLY person in Leesburg who crossed over the line? Yet::: only because he had such ammunition::: did he use it.  In closing::: this Country should be happy that I don't have the power to change things::: because while I hate bigotry::: I also hate an unfair playing field. No one::: regardless of color::: would be treated differently. You might say::: "That's all that we ask."::: but if you understood what that REALLY means::: no one::: regardless of race::: would appreciate it.

Last night::: Faculty Senate approved three temporary undergraduate academic policy changes for fall 2020. Students received an email this morning with information about these changes.  1) The deadline to drop fall 2020 classes (full semester and second session only) has been extended to Tuesday::: November 24::: 2020. This does not apply to first-session courses.  2) Students may appeal for a retroactive individual course withdrawal for a course they’ve received a letter grade of C- or below::: or an N-grade after final grades have been posted. Documentation will be required to support an appeal.  3) Students severely impacted by COVID-19 may request a change to their grading mode to S/CR/NC for one or more of their fall 2020 courses after final grades have been posted. More information on this process will be made available in early December.  Taking action on one or more of these policies may impact financial aid or degree progress. Students should contact their academic advisor to discuss their degree plan and a One Stop counselor about financial implications before making changes. More information about policy changes is available on the One Stop website.  ONESTOP.UTK.EDU Flexible Academic Policies – Fall 2020 and Spring 2021 | One Stop Student Services

column1: Experts from the UTK College of Education::: Health::: & Human Sciences have some helpful tips for families who are worried about their children's social development during the pandemic.  UTK College of Education::: Health::: & Human Sciences 6 October 2020 г.::: 15:53 ·  If you're worrying about how the COVID-19 pandemic will impact your child's social development::: Sally Hunter::: clinical associate professor in UTK Department of Child & Family Studies::: and other experts offered some helpful insight to The New York Times that just might ease your nerves: nyti.ms/2GohwgR  Important Note: This pandemic has caused a huge shift in everyone's lives::: from children to adults. Even though your child's social development is still on track::: it's important to pay attention to the ups and downs in their moods. If you notice a pattern of bad days or suffering grades::: their mental health may need some attending to.  -- University of Tennessee::: Knoxville UT Knoxville Alumni UTK Educational Psychology and Counseling University of Tennessee Department of Public Health

Calling all spring and summer 2020 grads! 🍊🎓  Please check your utk.edu email for info on the in-person commencement ceremonies planned for next month. We're excited to celebrate your accomplishments with you.  Ceremonies will be held Thursday::: Nov. 19::: though Sunday::: Nov. 22. Spring and summer 2020 grads also have the option to walk in May 2021. Registration for spring and summer grads to select their preferences will begin next week.  Health and safety guidelines will be observed at each ceremony and will limit the number of graduates::: guests::: and stage personnel. Masks and social distancing will be required.  Please continue to keep an eye on your utk.edu email for further information. These commencement ceremonies will be different from our usual format::: but we can't wait to celebrate with you.

The revised spring 2021 academic calendar is posted with changes to reduce the potential for travel-related spread of COVID-19 while maintaining the required number of instructional days. Read more at the link below.  Spring classes will begin on Wednesday::: January 20::: one week later than originally planned. There will be no spring break or no-class day (originally scheduled for April 1) in order to condense the semester. Spring recess will remain on April 2 and is a holiday with no classes. Spring semester classes will end on April 20::: with a study day scheduled on April 21. Final exams will begin on April 22.  Plans are in development to celebrate spring 2020::: summer 2020::: fall 2020::: and spring 2021 graduates. Event dates have not been set. Decisions will be shared as soon as they are finalized.  UTK.EDU Academic calendar

column1: Over the coming days::: current Massey Hall residents will begin moving into available spaces in other residence halls in order to create additional isolation housing for campus residents as COVID-19 cases increase in our campus community.  Massey residents received information this morning with additional details about housing refunds and move-out procedures. In order to prevent relocating students who have COVID-19::: personnel from the Student Health Center will test all Massey Hall residents before they move.  Students in other residence halls who currently have a vacancy in their room or suite may be assigned a new roommate or suite mate as Massey residents relocate. Students who have paid for a single room will not be assigned a roommate.  Instructors have been made aware of these moves and have been asked to remain flexible with students as these sudden changes add another level of stress to the semester.  For questions about the relocation process::: call 865-656-SAFE (7233). Students who are in distress or are having trouble navigating this difficult semester are encouraged to call 865-974-HELP (4357)::: which is staffed around the clock to support our Vols.  Read the message sent to Massey residents at the link below.  UTK.EDU Massey Hall Relocation Announcement
column3: Thank God my roommate teaches at USC (California) where they have chosen to be completely “on-line”. They have had some outbreaks with students living around campus::: but all teaching is virtual. It’s crazy that an university would think it’s a good idea to have students back on campus. This was putting profit over lives. Cal State (all campuses) have made their decision already to be virtual for next semester as well... I’m sure USC and others will follow. The students are driving the infection of Covid-19 in college towns. Sadly::: this will end up killing people unnecessarily so. I can’t wait until we have better leadership that is honest with the American public and leads us out of this crisis guided by science. We need unity to resolve this::: not division and distrust.

column3: Pets on Campus  For reasons of safety::: health::: and sanitation::: pets of any type are not allowed in any University-owne d building. This policy includes University residence halls.  EXCEPTIONS:  Service animals as defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Animals professionally trained for theatrical purposes and directly supervised by show personnel within a controlled environment. Any dogs or other domestic animals on University grounds must be in the control of their owners. Under no circumstances should animals be allowed to run loose or be tied to buildings::: handrails::: trees::: bicycle racks::: or other objects. Any infractions or complaints should be brought to the attention of the Department of Public Safety at extension 7777.  Rationale:  Health: Pets allowed in campus buildings pose health-related problems to building occupants. Examples of detrimental health effects associated with animal/human contact include::: but are not limited to: allergies associated with pet hair or urine; animal to human disease transmissions; the potential for animal bites. Safety: In the event of an emergency building evacuation::: animals in campus buildings have the potential to impede occupant egress.

column3: My son has all online classes. Now some of the classes have gone from being two times a week to one. One of his classes are now all videos. Professors teaching the classes I think not. column95: The Racial Matrix  For those of us who truly believe BLM::: Burn Loot Murder is a CRIMINALLY WICKED MOVEMENT.  BLM’s attacks on the police have resulted and will continue to result in more of the felonious violence that claims so many black victims – in L.A. alone::: homicides are up 250 percent since the recent riots.  BLM’s disruption of businesses and encouragement of looting may cow some white liberals now::: but they will ultimately increase anti-black sentiment and will slow blacks’ ability to rejoin a resurgent economy.  And BLM’s stated leftist commitment to “disrupt the Western-prescri bed nuclear family structure requirement” is just one more stage in the Left’s destruction of precisely that family structure that is the only hope of black children.  The Democrats think they can control this violent outfit and use them to protect the multi-billion-d ollar welfare patronage scam that has maintained their power base for 60 years while keeping blacks dependent and socially hobbled. It’s a cruel con. Because Democrats are in the pocket of corrupt teachers’ unions::: they destroy the charter schools that give black kids a chance. But they absolutely love BLM’s gobbledygook talk of “white supremacy” and “systemic racism” because those are amorphous nothings that can never be addressed. They therefore allow whites a warming sense of self-accusatory virtue while keeping blacks mired in endless self-destroying grievance politics that will never undermine the oppressive systems that profit Democrat elites.  Now::: because of the BLM-Democrat complex::: all of virtuous Washington is focused on police reform. Police Departments are powerful organizations and should always be on the lookout for ways to lighten their touch while still controlling crime. But while relations between police and black Americans may be problematical::: surely one important source of that trouble must be the extraordinary high crime rate in black neighborhoods. When 13 percent of the population – and it’s really six percent because we’re mostly talking about men – commit roughly 50 percent of the murders::: mostly of other blacks::: police reform is an issue on the margins.  Meanwhile::: because of Democrat welfare policies that encouraged irresponsible parenting::: Democrat feminist philosophy that discounted the worth of fathers::: and Democrat encouragement of sexual liberation that discounted the value of marriage::: blacks now have an illegitimacy rate higher than the bad old days when Democrat slavemasters were actually breaking up their families by design. Study after study shows that::: without fathers::: children are at high risk of failure::: substance abuse::: and crime. But no one has the guts to address this central issue.  The Democrat party is a cancer on black American lives. The latest stage of that cancer is Black Lives Matter.  Yet if you speak any of these truths online or out loud::: you are in danger of losing your job or your reputation. A UCLA college professor was suspended after he followed a university directive and refused to bow to virtue signaling white students’ demands to reschedule an exam for black students in the wake of George Floyd’s death. An NBA play-by-play announcer had to resign after tweeting “All Lives Matter.” And so on.  Corporations::: constrained by decades of restrictive and arbitrary civil rights legislation and law::: are terrified. They can be sued for just thinking racist thoughts::: and the evidence to prove the case against them can include some untoward remark some employee made ten years ago in the back of a taxi after a couple of drinks. No wonder they fire you if you say anything that might come back to haunt them.  The result is a fear of speaking the truth. Which means lies win. Which means the Left and its media have been allowed to create a Matrix – an entirely false narrative in which just those very prescriptions that will make black lives worse provide whites a sense of virtue while continuing the Democrat destruction of actual black lives.  My suspicion is that a great many black Americans know this. But they too are afraid. Their leaders are invested in this system. A scurrilous con man like Al Sharpton Junior draws all his prestige and power from it. Corrupt and incompetent black politicians around the country thrive in it. Stand up to them and you too will be penalized for transgressing the Matrix.  All people have tribal prejudices::: but Americans are not racist in any way that hampers success. Jamaicans and Nigerians succeed here. Koreans and Chinese and Indians and Japanese and Jews and everybody else.  Only that small segment of our society that has been the constant recipient of Democrat largesse and governance is continually mired in crime and dysfunction. That leads people to regard that segment with suspicion::: hostility::: and fear. Free blacks from the Democrats and they will rise like every other group in America.  "If we developed a vaccine to get rid of white racism::: would the major problems facing black America today still be there? The officer that shot the guy in Atlanta didn’t shoot him because he was black::: he shot him because he was trying to deploy a taser into his face.  The George Floyd situation is probably an overdose but the officer should have not been sitting on his neck at all. That guy might be a racist::: I don’t know::: but what I do know is that the officer is an idiot!  There are 800:::000 police officers in the United States. There’s no way there will not be an officer either make a poor decisions::: overreact::: or do something stupid. You can’t expect zero incidents from 800:::000 people that constantly have to deal with people resisting arrest.  I think real racism is being hijacked. column8: I think that the University of Tennessee at Knoxville should offer a number of online::: college credit courses leading to traditional Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science degrees and Master of Arts and Master of Science degrees. I still remember being a UT-K student::: in 1972. One of my classes as a General Psychology class which had 350 students::: met in one of the engineering halls and the lecture was by videotape. I was in a Western Civilization history class which had about 100 students and we watched the professor live on TV. UT also used to offer many correspondence courses::: for college credit. I took a sociological research course from UT::: via correspondence::: and found it very demanding and very excellent (passed it with a "B" ;>).

SPORTANDPEACE.ORG Tamika Catchings helps us launch our Global Disability Rights Advocacy Project  The Center for Sport::: Peace::: & Society 20 July 2020 г.::: 05:42 ·  When she was a child::: Tamika Catchings 🤩 remembers being teased for wearing hearing aids and the way she talked. Through basketball::: life experiences::: and the development of a fierce work ethic::: she overcame these challenges::: and::: now::: is helping other youth find their strength through basketball. 💪 Tamika knows what it feels like to be different and is an advocate for the inclusion of persons with disabilities and is paving the way for youth through her Catch the Stars Foundation ⭐ foundation.  For these reasons and more::: we’re thrilled to have Tamika help us launch our Global Disability Rights Advocacy Project!! 🙌 If you haven’t checked it out already::: head on over to 💥 sportandpeace.org 💥 to learn about the many ways you can create even more inclusive environments for persons with disabilities on your team::: at your school::: and in your community. The 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act 🇺🇸 is coming up soon::: and we’re excited to plant seeds of inclusion here in Tennessee 🧡 and across the world. 🌏  🗺️ Explore our global map: https://sportandpeace.com/global-map/  🏆 Download our toolkit: https://sportandpeace.com/documents/CSPS_AdvocacySocialChange_Toolkit.pdf  📍 Discover something new: https://sportandpeace.com/all-timeline/  💻 Check out our website: https://sportandpeace.com  University of Tennessee::: Knoxville UTK College of Education::: Health::: & Human Sciences Kinesiology::: Recreation::: & Sport Studies UTK Diversity Affairs UTK Center for Global Engagement Sports Diplomacy - U.S. Department of State U.S. Department of State Exchange Programs - U.S. Department of State Indiana Fever UT President Randy Boyd Beyond Sport Peace and Sport The International Platform on Sport and Development UT Knoxville Alumni  #inclusion #disability #PWD #disabilityawareness #disabilityrights #disabilityadvocate #ThanksToTheADA #ADA30 #ADAanniversary #diversity #inclusionmatters #community #equality #accessibility #diversityandinclusion #mentorship #leadership #entrepreneurship #motivation #inspiration #basketball #adaptivesports

column1: Fall tuition and fees were originally scheduled to be assessed on July 10. However::: in order to allow students time to finalize their fall schedules::: the university will not assess fall fees until July 24.

column10: There should be no mandatory meal plan fees::: no transportation fees::: health clinic fees - if you have proof of health insurance::: no add-on building fees::: study abroad fees::: no program fees since UTK is not providing any. Where is the actual support for the students::: here? Are you making professors actually work 40 hours a week with regular on-line office hours at a minimum? This was not the case in the spring which is why parents & students are disappointed. My son had a class where a professor just uploaded files Mid-March never to be heard from again with 2 tests following. What about career fairs? Further::: UTK knew this was going to happen and did not make the announcement sooner for nearly all on-line classes. This would have allowed families to make better housing and course decisions. No in person classes along with all the other social restrictions is not worth the housing expense let alone the isolation impact to mental health. EVERY CLASS should have at least 1 hour in person a week. Surely with the amount of space::: time and smart people::: someone could have developed a better plan with socially distanced interactions vs. no interactions. The most irritating of all is that the statistical probability of serious illness in young people remains extremely low. Is the treatment worse than the disease? Time will tell.

column1: Changes to federal policy about international students and online courses have caused concern among many in our campus community.  The Center for Global Engagement will work with international students to help them comply with the law::: have a meaningful educational experience::: and continue to study at the university. Options available to our students include hybrid courses::: independent study::: and graduate seminars.  The university has approximately 1:::060 international students representing 95 countries. They are scholars::: contributors to campus life::: and valued members of the Volunteer family.  International students::: please contact UTK Center for Global Engagement for any assistance you may need. https://cge.utk.edu/
column3: I am so disappointed in my University of Tennessee. Open up::: have classes for students and have international students on a list to enter after you have serviced this population. We have students here who have been unnoticed their entire lives in the Knoxville Community. Open classes. Not all can afford WiFi in their residences. We are a Land-grant University...Ac t like one. It's about EDUCATION.
column4: We are a family who hosted an international student for a year in our home. And we loved the entire experience. So we are in support of helping the international community. (Even though the Universities get lots of incentives to have a significant population of internationals) Over the past two weeks::: we have watched day by day our incoming freshman son’s classes leach to online classes one by one. It is quite disheartening for students who have lost so much already this year. Freshmen should have at least some priority to in-person classes since they are the majority of students on campus.

column1: Updates to fall class times and locations will be finalized on Monday::: July 13. Students should wait until July 13 before adjusting their schedules. column1: The University of Tennessee::: Knoxville::: has received a number of complaints of racist remarks made by students and incoming students over the past week.  In one case::: we alerted police::: placed the student on immediate interim suspension::: and now the student is no longer enrolled at the university. In another::: an incoming student will also not be attending UT after racist materials surfaced.  We will use the university’s bias process to review every case that comes in. You can submit a bias report on the Dean of Students website at https://bias.utk.edu/::: which includes the ability to upload screenshots or other supporting documentation.  We are committed to protecting our Black students and colleagues. We will do the hard work to lead::: learn::: and create an equitable community that values and respects all people.

column1: The University of Tennessee has received several reports of racist remarks and actions on social media by past::: present::: and future members of our community. The university takes seriously our commitment to fostering a Volunteer community that values equity::: inclusion and that promotes respect for all people. We have a responsibility to support our black students and create a place where all Vols feel safe. On Wednesday::: following a racist video and photo surfacing on social media::: Athletics made the decision not to allow a prospective student to join the Spirit Program. She will not be attending the university this fall.  Anytime the university receives a report::: it is reviewed. Any reports relating to current students will go through existing bias reporting processes. We review and address issues as they come up with the individuals involved.

column13: University of Tennessee::: Knoxville  This is great::: but make sure that you at taking action every day::: not just while this movement is trending.  I attended the university for 4 years and I know of several complaints made with video and picture evidence about racist remarks that went unaddressed.  I also saw the university make detrimental cuts to diversity programs in my time there. You cannot claim to be an institutional ally while also cutting resources and access from your Black students and students of color. If you want to help beat systematic racism then you need to build diversity within the university and lift those voices up.  This is a great start::: but make no mistake. We have a long way to go in the Vol community.
